ratings.question_text: I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: What is the name of your TA?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: I felt the organization of the course could be improved. We learned a lot from case studies, but they did not follow a logical progression (such as that which is outlined in the book). Maybe if we had followed the outline of the book rather than jumping around within the book, the order of the cases would have made more sense.
Instead of all case readings, have supplementary readings that provide different perspectives.

1: I would have appreciated a little more variety in the readings. Perhaps, in addition to presenting cases, each week a student could discuss a "current event" involving zoning or land use of some sort.
Shansky is a magnificent teacher. Excellent use of socratic method!

Question 2 - often the material could have been made more clear by having clearly defined topics. when the instructor discussed something with writing on the board, sometimes it was hard to catch on to where the discussion fit into the overall framework of the topic
Learning from practical examples. Also, being invited to hearings and learning from Marjorie about real cases on which she is working.
It is useful class for life skills. Many of the things learned are useful to know, even if they are not directly linked with what your interests are.
Learning from Attorney Shanksy's extensive experience with local land use law. It was also neat how Attorney Shanksy offered to take us to community meetings, too.
The instructor's in depth knowledge
Class discussions
ProjectHate to say this, but the midterm. It really forced me to think about what I'd learned.
Presenting cases each week, optional field trips, final project
Ms. Shansky. She is very knowledgeable and enjoyable to listen to.
class discussions
Vibrant narrative on the part of Atty. ShanskyInteresting case readings
Prof.Shansky who was lively and engaging.
Marjorie is awesome. It's clear that she is an expert in the subject and excited about teaching it. She was great.

The information learned is very important for any individual living in a municipality to know. Not only was it a course that advanced my academic interests, on a personal level it also made me aware of key issues to consider when developing property and working to conserve natural resources on a local scale.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: See above re: organization.
I liked this class a lot, no suggestions

I think that if it were a little bit clearer what we were supposed to get out of the various cases and lecture, it would be a much stronger course. I think that I tended to focus on the wrong parts of the readings and sometimes of the lectures. It would also be useful to clarify precisely what the connection between the lectures and the readings are each week.

I think I would have learned more if the course focused more on themes and not so much on individual cases. Summarizing cases together in class that we were assigned to read as homework is not the best use of class time. I would have liked to hear Attorney Shanksy lecture more. We needed to talk more about the links between cases more, too.
An outline of the subject material. It seemed a little bit too free form at times.
More focus at the beginning of the course on defining and clarifying the roles of various local agencies and laws.

There needs to be a better way to learn the cases. Maybe we can break into groups and present more frequently, writing things like 'Facts/Holding/Reasoning' on the white board. It's hard to get what we need to know out of the cases by just reading and listening to someone present.Also, the class focuses mostly on cases, but the midterm was mostly practical stuff. I think practical stuff needs to be taught separately from cases. There are no black and whites with the practical, but understanding who does what and when, what the midterm focused on, was hard for everyone to learn, and is probably the most valuable part of the course.
A little more variety in readings/class assignments would be nice.
Course organization/scheduling

Some of the legal concepts were not as clearly presented as one might hope. I think the format of students presenting cases would be better if students were asked to present the takeaways from each case more clearly. I think a room where everyone faced each other would be more conducive to good conversation.
More structure to the lectures would be useful. Concepts + applications. The course was application-heavy, and so the important concepts were frequently lost after going over the readings.

The organizational framework. Although cases and presenting of cases is useful. The class was mostly student presentations with random comments and interludes by the professor. I would have liked to see more teaching on her part to present the topics and then we could have group discussion for how the cases relate to the topics.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: We did not have a TA.
Great, the professor was always available for advice.
The professor was at all points extremely responsive - far beyond average.
Excellent-- thanks!
Very available.
good for both
Available for discussion outside of class and very flexible. Excellent and helpful.
Prof. Shansky was very available and helpful. I especially appreciate the connections she offers in communities around CT.
Marjorie was readily available to chat with us about concepts and give advice on our projects.
Private meetings were helpful to discuss the final project

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: Law and policy
This course is a must take for those interested in architecture and local land-use planning.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I took this course to learn more about local environmental law and its practical application to development projects.
To fulfill a law requirement
I am interested in land use as it relates to urban planning.
Felt that it was important to have a solid understand of land use law
Local law course are not offered in law school. I have exposure to federal and state environmental law but not local.
Wanted to understand how local environmental law works / become familiar with the language and land use processes
I wanted to learn the legal framework to land use to understand why things are the way they are...so they can be changed.
Gain a basic exposure to local land use practice and environmental regulation
It fulfilled a requirement for me. Otherwise I would not have taken it.
I wanted to learn about zoning regulations.

comments: Yes.
Yes, and more
Yes!
I wish that we had spent more time on IDEAS and STRATEGIES instead of on the details of specific cases. Other than that, yes.
Yes
Yes!
Yes although see #13.
yes!
Absolutely
yes.
Yes

comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: You will get out of the class what you put in. Select a project that aligns with your personal/academic interests.
Do the reading, It makes the course so much more enjoyable.
Take the course, its great.
Don't focus on the case law. You get the most out of the practical stuff.
Shansky is a delightful, animated professor and makes all of the material interesting. Definitely worth taking.
Do the reading prior to class; discussion is far more interesting when you have done the reading.
Select a project early in the course
You get what you put into the class. The reading is light but interesting.
